questions.prompt: The capacitor voltage continuity property states that:
options: v_C always equals the source voltage
v_C(T⁺) = v_C(T⁻) when current is bounded
v_C can jump at any time
v_C equals zero at switching instants
questions.correctAnswer: v_C(T⁺) = v_C(T⁻) when current is bounded
questions.explanation: When the current through a capacitor remains bounded (finite), the voltage cannot change instantaneously. This follows from v(T+dt)−v(T) = (1/C)∫i·dt → 0 as dt → 0.

questions.prompt: An inductor carrying 3A has its circuit switched at t=0. The current i_L(0⁺) is:
questions.explanation: By inductor current continuity: i_L(0⁺) = i_L(0⁻) = 3A. The current cannot jump. The new circuit determines how i_L changes FOR t > 0, but at t = 0⁺, it equals its pre-switch value.

questions.prompt: The unit impulse function δ(t) has:
options: Infinite height, zero width, unit area
questions.correctAnswer: Infinite height, zero width, unit area
questions.explanation: The impulse δ(t) is the limit of progressively narrower, taller pulses whose area remains exactly 1. It's zero everywhere except t=0 where it's singular, and ∫δ(t)dt = 1.

questions.prompt: A current impulse i(t) = Aδ(t) applied to a capacitor C produces:
options: A voltage step of magnitude A/C
questions.correctAnswer: A voltage step of magnitude A/C
questions.explanation: v_C = (1/C)∫Aδ(τ)dτ = A/C for t > 0. The impulse deposits charge A instantaneously, raising the voltage by A/C = q/C.

questions.prompt: In the impulse derivation, what stays constant as Δ → 0?
questions.explanation: The height goes to infinity and width to zero, but their product (the area = CE) stays constant. This constant area becomes the 'strength' of the impulse.

questions.prompt: Which quantities CAN jump discontinuously at a switching instant?
questions.explanation: Only state variables (v_C and i_L) are guaranteed continuous. Resistor voltages, capacitor currents, and other non-state quantities CAN and often DO jump at switching instants.

questions.prompt: Why does opening a switch on an inductor carrying current cause arcing?
options: v = L·di/dt becomes very large when i changes rapidly
The inductor acts as a voltage source
questions.correctAnswer: v = L·di/dt becomes very large when i changes rapidly
questions.explanation: When a switch opens, di/dt is extremely large (current forced to zero quickly). v = L·di/dt produces a very high voltage spike across the switch gap, ionizing the air and causing an arc.

questions.prompt: The substitution theorem allows you to:
options: Replace any element with a short circuit
Replace a capacitor/inductor with an equivalent voltage or current source
Eliminate all sources from the circuit
questions.correctAnswer: Replace a capacitor/inductor with an equivalent voltage or current source
questions.explanation: If the circuit has a unique solution v̂(t) across a port, the element at that port can be replaced by a source v̂(t) without affecting the rest of the circuit. This is essential for solving first-order circuits.

questions.prompt: If a 10μF capacitor has v_C(0⁻) = 3V and a bounded current flows, v_C(0⁺) equals:
questions.explanation: By the continuity property, v_C(0⁺) = v_C(0⁻) = 3V. The capacitor voltage at the instant just after switching equals the voltage just before switching, regardless of the new circuit topology.
